SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. These symptoms have been present for about five weeks. He has been experiencing shortness of breath during physical activities and slight chest cramps that resolve after about an hour. He also reports a slight cough. The patient has been adhering to his medications, but his diet has been off due to recent home renovations and eating out more frequently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fevers, chills. Positive fatigue and lightheadedness.
• Cardiovascular: Positive bloating, shortness of breath, and chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Positive cough.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
• Psychiatric: Denies anxiety.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Vital signs within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 centimeters.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Monitor weight daily and report any significant weight gain or shortness of breath. Order a new echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure appears well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevated readings through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain after a fall from a ladder while changing a light bulb. She twisted her knee while trying to catch her fall. The incident occurred yesterday.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Digoxin

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Atrial Fibrillation, Rhinoplasty

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. There is pain with flexion and valgus stress. Normal sensation in the lower leg.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain/strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend a prescription for Motrin 800 mg every 6 hours with food, dispense a two-week supply. The patient will be provided with a knee brace and crutches for temporary use. She will return in 1 week for a follow-up, and if not improved, an MRI will be ordered. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain. The patient reports lifting heavy boxes too quickly, which resulted in a popping sound and pain in his lower back. This occurred on Saturday morning, and the pain has persisted since then. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and Icy Hot, but these have provided minimal relief. The patient experienced tingling in the toes of his right foot, which resolved by Sunday afternoon.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion. Endorses a 2/6 systolic heart murmur.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies hematemesis, hematochezia, melena, heartburn, or abdominal pain.
• Genitourinary: Denies urinary urgency, pain, or incontinence.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower back pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. 2/6 systolic heart murmur. No extra heart sounds.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

RESULTS

X-ray of the lumbar spine is unremarkable. Normal bony alignment. No fractures were noted.

Labs: Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lumbar strain:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient reports lower back pain after lifting heavy boxes. X-ray of the lumbar spine is unremarkable.
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing and avoid strenuous activity.
   • Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy.

2. Diabetes type 2:
   • Medical Reasoning: Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice a day. Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

3. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are slightly elevated.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

4. Osteoarthritis:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee osteoarthritis well.
   • Medical Treatment: No further workup needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension, who presents for his annual exam. The patient reports managing his depression well with Prozac and has not had any incidents recently. He has been struggling with hypertension, taking Norvasc regularly during the business week but sometimes forgetting on weekends. He also experiences shortness of breath with exertion, particularly during humid conditions while running 4-5 miles daily. He endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Vital Signs: Blood pressure 120/80 mmHg in the office today.

Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Extremities: No lower extremity edema.

Head and Neck: Pain to palpation of sinuses, indicating congestion.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.

Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression: The patient is managing well on Prozac 20 mg daily. Continue the current regimen and provide a refill for the medication.

2. Prior lobectomy: The patient's breathing function is fine, and he is exercising regularly. No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed at this time.

3. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is well-controlled in the office today. Encourage continued adherence to the Norvasc medication regimen. Order an echocardiogram to evaluate the systolic ejection murmur. 

4. Nasal congestion: Likely due to pollen. Monitor and manage symptoms as needed.

The patient will have routine blood work ordered, and the results will be communicated through the patient portal. The patient understands and agrees with the assessment and plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain. She reports that she was skiing over the weekend and while going over moguls, her ski strap caught on her finger, causing it to bend back. The incident occurred on Sunday. She has tried applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but the pain persists. She rates her pain as worse with movement. She has a history of constipation and takes Miralax. She has a past surgical history of an appendectomy at age 18. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx and pain with flexion. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Patient is able to bend and extend the finger and touch her thumb with it.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and everything lines up well.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we provide her with an aluminum foam splint and prescribe Motrin, 600 mg, to take every 6 hours for one week. If the pain does not improve, the patient is advised to call and return for further evaluation. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia. She presents today after being unable to donate blood in December 2019 due to her anemia. The patient reports feeling fatigued, feverish with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also mentions increased sensitivity to cold and worsening anxiety and depression. She has been anemic since she was 13 years old and had a hysterectomy in 1996.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Fatigue, feverish with chills, sensitivity to cold.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath, wheezing.
• Neurological: Headaches.
• Psychiatric: Worsening anxiety and depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds.
• Respiratory: Clear lung sounds.
• Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no masses or organomegaly.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia and presents with symptoms of fatigue, shortness of breath, and headaches. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.
• Additional Testing: Schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 12 weeks.
• Medical Treatment: Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily, taken with orange juice for better absorption. Refer to a hematologist for further evaluation and possible intravenous iron or other treatments.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy and a referral to a hematologist. Provide instructions for bowel prep and advise the patient to call if they have any questions or worsening symptoms.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion discovery.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 52-year-old male who presents with worsening headaches over the past few months. He denies any history of headaches. His past clinical history is unremarkable. Workup for headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where a pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Labs and imaging were reviewed, with normal results except for a low TSH and the pituitary lesion. The MRI reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The patient reports bumping into door frames recently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Neurological: Endorses worsening headaches, bumping into door frames.
• Ophthalmologic: Bitemporal hemianopia noted on visual field testing.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person.
• Neurological: Cranial nerve examination grossly intact, no focal motor or sensory deficits in upper or lower extremities.
• Ophthalmologic: Visual acuity and eye movements normal, pupils equal and reactive, color vision normal.

ASSESSMENT

Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is symptomatic with clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression.
• Medical Treatment: Surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa is indicated. Transsphenoidal approach planned. Pre-surgery visual field test ordered.

Worsening headaches.
• Medical Reasoning: Likely related to the pituitary lesion and optic chiasmal compression.
• Medical Treatment: Surgical intervention to address the pituitary lesion may alleviate headaches.

PLAN

1. Schedule surgery for pituitary adenoma excision and decompression.
2. Refer the patient for a pre-surgery visual field test.
3. Follow up with the patient after surgery to assess vision improvement and headache resolution.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal. She presents today as a new patient with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. She experienced chest pain and difficulty swallowing in early October 2020, which resolved after four days. The patient has not had any recurrence of these symptoms since then. She reports that she was going through a stressful job transition at the time of the symptoms.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies any current chest pain.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain, normal bowel movements. Endorses mild tenderness in the upper abdominal quadrants.
• Psychiatric: Reports stress related to job transition.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Normal cardiac workup from ER visit.
• Gastrointestinal: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No other abnormalities noted.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal, who presents today with a referral from the ER for esophagitis.

Possible etiologies:
• GERD
• Dyspepsia
• Esophagitis
• Musculoskeletal etiologies
• Anxiety

Suspect she had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, plus or minus a contribution from her musculoskeletal etiologies.

Plan:
• Discussed the option of EGD versus monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change.
• Follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CC:

Evaluation of Smith-Magenis Syndrome in a 22-month-old female patient.

HPI:

Katherine is a 22-month-old female who presents today for an evaluation of Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin and has a history of developmental delays, including not walking or sitting by herself at one year old. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will be starting speech therapy soon. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The patient's mother reports that Katherine has normal wet diaper output (8-10 per day) and drinks a good amount of fluids.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Smith-Magenis Syndrome, developmental delays, reflux, and temperature regulation issues.

EXAM:

Physical examination shows a well-nourished female who is slightly fussy when examined. Eyes are small appearing. She has mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia.

IMPRESSION:

Smith-Magenis Syndrome with potential congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and plan with the patient's mother. We will obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for any abnormalities. If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up with our clinic will be needed. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist injury.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a female who presents with a right wrist injury sustained while walking up and down the stairs doing laundry. She slipped and tried to catch herself, resulting in immediate pain and swelling in her right wrist. The injury occurred yesterday morning. The patient denies any previous injuries to this arm. She rates the pain as 9/10 in severity. She has tried ice, an ace wrap, and ibuprofen for pain relief, but the pain persists.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right wrist pain and swelling.
• Neurological: Endorses mild numbness and tingling in fingers.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: in no apparent distress.
• Neck: Supple without thyromegaly.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
• Musculoskeletal: Obvious swelling and bruising of the right wrist. Pain on palpation and movement. Limited range of motion due to pain. Bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist: Positive for a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

The patient presents with a right wrist injury consistent with a Colles' fracture.

• Medical Reasoning: The patient's history, physical examination, and x-ray findings support the diagnosis of a Colles' fracture.
• Medical Treatment: The patient will be provided with a brace for immobilization. Surgery is recommended, and the patient will be scheduled for the procedure as soon as possible. Post-surgery, the patient will be referred to physical therapy. Pain management will include Ultram 50 mg every 6 hours. The patient will be advised to follow up in one month to assess progress and discuss upcoming vacation plans.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Philip is a 45-year-old male who presents with right knee pain after slipping and falling while working on his property a week ago. He reports feeling a pop during the fall and has experienced pain and swelling since the incident. The patient rates his pain as 4 out of 10 when moving the knee. He has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief and swelling.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, managed with 20 mg lisinopril.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Non-smoker, occasional alcohol consumption.

FAMILY HISTORY

Non-contributory.

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
Respiratory: Lungs clear bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.
Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the medial aspect of the right knee, pain with flexion and extension, edema around the knee, and effusion present.

RESULTS

Right knee X-ray: No fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice a day for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times a day. Advise the patient to elevate and rest the leg.

2. Hypertension: Continue lisinopril 20 mg. Refer the patient to a nutritionist for dietary management and support to potentially reduce the need for medication in the future.

The patient was advised on the treatment plan, and all questions were answered. The patient expressed understanding and agreed to proceed with the recommendations.

CC:

Left shoulder pain.

HPI:

Mr. Wayne is a patient who presents today with left shoulder pain that has been ongoing for approximately three weeks. He is unable to recall any specific injury but has been active and recently working on renovating his basement. He has had occasional aches and pains in the past but nothing that Tylenol couldn't alleviate. The pain is constant and worsens with pressure or reaching for objects. He has been taking two extra strength Tylenol every six to eight hours for pain relief, which helps but does not completely alleviate the pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

None mentioned.

EXAM:

Left shoulder exam shows limited active and passive range of motion, tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus, and no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grips. Neurovascular exam of the left arm shows capillary refill less than three seconds and sensation intact to light touch.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left shoulder show no fractures.

IMPRESSION:

Left shoulder pain, likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN:

1. Order an MRI for the left shoulder to further evaluate the issue.
2. Refer the patient to physical therapy for approximately six to eight weeks.
3. Continue taking Tylenol for pain relief as needed.
4. Consider a steroid injection for the shoulder if symptoms do not improve after physical therapy.
5. Schedule a follow-up visit after the completion of physical therapy.

All questions were answered, and the patient was provided with educational materials on physical therapy.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a patient who presents with occasional left knee pain and instability. She reports that her knee occasionally gives out while walking, but the pain does not last long. She denies any history of injury to the knee and has not taken any pain medication for it. The patient has a trip planned in the next month and is concerned about participating in line dancing due to her knee issue.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Farxiga, Amlodipine, Lisinopril, Hydrochlorothiazide, and Metformin.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.

Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Left Knee: No ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability - likely arthritis.
2. Hypertension - controlled on medication.
3. Diabetes Mellitus - controlled on medication.

PLAN

1. Prescribe Meloxicam 15 mg daily for left knee pain and consider physical therapy to strengthen muscles around the knee.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur.
3. Order Hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to Metformin.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow up in 4 weeks to reevaluate knee pain and discuss results of echocardiogram, Hemoglobin A1c, and lipid panel.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy for stage three non-small cell lung cancer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Beverly is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She presents for follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, and biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending at this time.

The patient reports minimal cough and sore throat today. She has experienced some fatigue but denies nausea or vomiting. She has a dry cough and no shortness of breath. She has been eating but not as much as she normally would.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Respiratory: Endorses minimal cough and sore throat.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or difficulty swallowing.
• General: Endorses fatigue.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Within normal limits, including oxygen saturation.
• Neck: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
• Respiratory: Crackles in lungs bilaterally.
• Skin: Erythema on the anterior side of the left chest, likely related to radiation.
• Extremities: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Stage three non-small cell lung cancer: Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of radiation to assess for surgical resection.

2. Radiation pneumonitis: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and improve cough and shortness of breath.

3. Painful swallowing: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow four times a day to alleviate pain and improve oral intake.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level

HPI:

Mr. Kyle is a recently diagnosed type 2 diabetic patient who was referred by his PCP for evaluation of a low IgA level. The patient reports frequent colds during the wintertime and states that they tend to linger for a long time. He denies any recent abdominal infections or diarrhea. He has no known family history of immune deficiencies. He recently traveled to Zambia but has not received any blood transfusions or blood products.

EXAM:

Vitals are within normal limits, with no fever. Heart exam shows regular rate and rhythm with no murmurs. Lung exam reveals clear lungs with no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. Neck exam shows no lymphadenopathy. Abdominal exam is soft and non-tender.

RESULTS:

Recent lab work confirms low IgA level.

IMPRESSION:

IgA deficiency

PLAN:

1. Order additional blood work to check for other immunodeficiencies.
2. Educate the patient on the importance of monitoring for infections and informing healthcare providers of his IgA deficiency, especially if receiving blood products.
3. Follow up with the patient after lab results are available to discuss any further management or concerns.

CC:

Right elbow pain.

HPI:

Mr. Lawrence is a patient who presents today for an evaluation of right elbow pain. He reports that he has been doing a lot of pottery during the pandemic and developed elbow pain over the past week. The pain is located on the inside of his right elbow and can radiate down into his forearm. He rates the pain as a 6/10 and states that it keeps him up at night and affects his ability to perform certain activities. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success. The pain has been ongoing for about four days. No history of trauma or previous right elbow injury.

EXAM:

Vitals are within normal limits. Examination of the right elbow shows moderate tenderness to the medial epicondyle. No pain with wrist supination, but pain is present with wrist pronation. Pain is also present with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right elbow show no fractures or bony abnormalities.

IMPRESSION:

Medial epicondylitis.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended the following:
1. Rest and wear a sling while awake.
2. Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Take ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for a full week.
4. Avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
5. Follow-up appointment in one week to assess progress.

The patient agrees to the plan and will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient reports experiencing chest pain and shortness of breath while walking outside. He fell and was taken to the emergency department. He has a history of hypertension and has been taking prescribed medications, but occasionally misses doses. The patient admits to not following a strict diet and consuming salty foods.

PAST HISTORY

Hypertension.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient quit smoking a couple of years ago but occasionally has one cigarette per week.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Bumex tablet.
Cozaar tablet.
Norvasc tablet.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Blood pressure 128/72, other vital signs within normal limits.
Neck: No jugular venous distention.
Heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
Lungs: Clear bilaterally.
Lower extremities: Trace edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram: Preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT

• Congestive heart failure likely due to dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
• Hypertension.

PLAN

1. Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily.
2. Continue Cozaar 100 mg daily.
3. Continue Norvasc 5 mg once daily.
4. Consult with nutritionist for dietary advice.
5. Weigh daily and report weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days.
6. Obtain a home blood pressure cuff and monitor blood pressure regularly.
7. Order renal artery ultrasound to rule out other causes.
8. Follow up with the patient to monitor progress and adjust treatment as needed.

INSTRUCTIONS

1. Take medications as prescribed and do not miss doses.
2. Consult with a nutritionist for dietary advice.
3. Monitor weight and blood pressure daily.
4. Follow up with the doctor for further evaluation and management.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain and suspected kidney stone.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient experiencing sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain comes and goes, and when it comes, it is severe. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for the pain, but it has not been effective. The patient feels nauseated but has not vomited. He has a family history of kidney stones and has had them before.

PAST HISTORY

Kidney stones.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Father had kidney stones.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Gastrointestinal: Right-sided abdominal pain, nausea.
• Genitourinary: Burning sensation during urination, dark-colored urine.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdominal
No tenderness to palpation, no evidence of rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.

CVA tenderness
Positive on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen shows a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

• Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage the patient to push fluids to facilitate urination and help pass the stone.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain, alternating with Tylenol.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to strain urine and collect the stone for testing.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks to assess progress and discuss further treatment options, such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy, if necessary.
6. Instruct the patient to contact the provider if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient reports having a non-healing foot ulcer on the right foot for approximately six weeks. The ulcer began as a blister after wearing tight shoes and has since progressed to an open wound with foul-smelling yellow drainage and blackened tissue around the edges. The patient has been on antibiotics for six days and has experienced some improvement, but the wound has not healed completely. The patient also reports cramping in the calf muscle and red streaks along the inside of the calf muscle, as well as difficulty catching breath and coughing.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Diabetes mellitus with diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient enjoys hiking and recently hiked on new trails.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Antibiotics for foot ulcer.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
Foot Exam: Necrotic wound on the right heel, approximately 2x2 cm, with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythema. No bony exposure. No palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Vascular Exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses.

RESULTS

Right foot x-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT

Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer with cellulitis and possible vascular insufficiency.

PLAN

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement in the office today.
3. Obtain a culture of the wound and adjust antibiotic therapy as needed.
4. Monitor the redness and swelling in the patient's calf.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in seven days.
6. Encourage the patient to follow up with their endocrinologist to manage diabetes and maintain hemoglobin A1C below 7.

INSTRUCTIONS

Continue current antibiotic therapy and await culture results. Follow up with endocrinologist for diabetes management. Return for a follow-up appointment in seven days.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite.
Possible Lyme disease.
Hypertension.
Diabetes.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Richard is a middle-aged male who presents today with a tick bite around his knee. He reports spending time outdoors and recently went hunting. The tick bite has been present for over a week and is causing burning and discomfort. He denies fever or chills but reports feeling generally unwell and experiencing headaches since the tick bite. He has no difficulty moving his knee or walking. He has had tick bites in the past but has never been diagnosed with Lyme disease.

Richard also reports taking lisinopril for hypertension and metformin for diabetes. He checks his blood pressure periodically and believes it is well-controlled. He is also monitoring his blood sugar levels, which have been running around 120 with metformin.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Hypertension.
Diabetes.
Arthritis.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
Metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

ALLERGIES

No known allergies.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: BP 122/70, HR 67, Temp 98.4°F.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmur, rub, or gallop.
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Right knee: Erythema, edema, area of fluctuance over right patella, pain to palpation, full range of motion.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT

• Possible Lyme disease.
• Hypertension.
• Diabetes.
• Arthritis.

PLAN

Possible Lyme disease
Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for three weeks. Order Lyme titer and Western blot tests. Monitor response to treatment and consider further intervention if necessary.

Hypertension
Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

Diabetes
Order hemoglobin A1c. Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily. Monitor blood sugar levels and adjust treatment as needed.

Arthritis
No specific intervention at this time.

Kidney function
Order basic metabolic panel to assess kidney function.

INSTRUCTIONS

Richard will follow up in the clinic as needed and will report any worsening symptoms or concerns.
